title: Heartbroken mum fell to her knees and screamed as she found baby dead in his cot
text:

A heartbroken mum fell to her knees as she discovered her nine-month-old baby dead in his cot after she says he was tangled up in the bed's bumper.

Lisa Gee quickly dialled 999 despite knowing there was nothing paramedics could do for Preston Brian.

She described screaming and telling the operator “please help me, my baby is dead," Bristol Live reports.

Lisa said it was when her partner Cuchulain Brian went to pick the baby up that he realised the bumper was "wrapped around his neck".

"I fell to my knees and felt like I’d died the most painful death," Lisa said in a post on Facebook .

Since Preston's death six years ago, Lisa, from Leicestershire, has devoted her life to raising awareness and warning other parents about the dangers of cot bumpers.

The 32-year-old's work is a lasting legacy for Preston.

(Image: Daily Mirror)

The nine-month-old was found with his cot bumper "wrapped around his neck" in September 2013.

An inquest later concluded there was no evidence that a "loose" bumper led to his passing and recorded a verdict of 'sudden death in infancy'.

The Mirror has previously reported that grieving Lisa and partner Cuc do not accept the ruling.

Health advice and the law have both been updated thanks to Lisa's campaigning, Bristol Live reports.

Lisa is still however urging for a ban on cot bumpers.

Speaking to the Mirror Online today, she said: "Although we are extremely happy with the changes that have been made since Preston’s death regarding introducing cot bumpers into current safe sleep advice and the update to safety laws across Europe, our original goal hasn’t changed and we will still be pushing for a ban once we have drummed up enough support to get a petition to meet the 100,000 requirement.

"When we first started this we didn’t think it would do as well as it has, we didn’t think many would listen or that we’d make such amazing changes so it’s mind blowing to us when we see hundreds of comments on posts about safe sleep and bumpers mentioning Preston’s name - especially when we had to fight tooth and nail for the original 10,000 signatures that started the updated safety law.

"I think given the amount of support we’re gaining from people on a daily basis we won’t be waiting long until we can try again and we’re so grateful to everybody who has played a part in that.

"It’s not something I’m ever going to give up on and if it takes until my last breath to make sure this doesn’t keep happening then that’s what it will have to be."

(Image: Mirrorpix)

Describing the dreadful day she lost her son, Lisa previously said: "You’d think you’d know, you have a connection with your children after carrying them for nine months but I didn’t know.

"I didn’t feel dread, it felt like a normal day. I went downstairs to find Cuc (Cuchulain) in the kitchen supervising our daughter eating her breakfast.

"He put our daughter in front of the TV and I sat down with her. A minute later I heard a moan, the only way I can describe it is like a wounded animal.

"We had two dogs so I thought they were playing, I shouted through to them to “pack it up”.

"Seconds went by and my stomach dropped, I felt the dread I should’ve felt earlier, I shouted 'what?' No reply “'what?'

"Again, the feeling of dread got stronger so I ran up the stairs. That’s when my life changed. I found Cuc in Preston’s bedroom door cradling our baby, fighting back tears, time had stopped."

She continued: "I screamed, screamed like I’d never screamed before and ran down the stairs still screaming and grabbed the phone from the dock at the bottom and dialled 999.

"When the operator answered everything was in slow motion and she was asking what service I needed.

"I was confused so I screamed “all of them, please help me, my baby is dead”

"She asked me to take the phone upstairs, I didn’t want to because I didn’t want to see my baby gone, all I’d seen was the back of his head before that but I ran the phone upstairs and found Cuc in our bedroom trying to revive Preston but it was obvious we were too late, he was grey, I fell to my knees and felt like I’d died the most painful death."

(Image: Mirrorpix)

It wasn't until Lisa was in hospital she found out how her baby had died.

"When we identified Preston he looked so peaceful, for a second I thought he was asleep.

"I bent down and stroked his head, I begged him to wake up and we could go home, " said Lisa.

"I stroked his hair, I remember touching him and he felt empty, I could feel the life that was inside of him was gone.

"That night I couldn’t stay at home, I stayed with a friend and I vowed I would make some good come from this, when I got home I opened the laptop and Googled “cot bumper deaths” there was loads, I felt sick, if I’d have done that sooner Preston would be here now.

"That’s when I made this page , there was no time to lose and I knew bumpers were on cots all around the world, I needed to reach people immediately and that’s what we did.

"Six years later Preston’s death wasn’t in vain, he died for a reason. Advice has changed, laws have changed all because we stood up.

"Despite the changes made babies have still died, unnecessarily."
description: Since Preston's tragic death, Lisa Gee has devoted her life to raising awareness and warning other parents about the dangers of cot bumpers
